body_text.text: In this study, we aimed to evaluate the diagnostic value of serological assay for 34 SARS-CoV-2. A newly-developed ELISA assay for IgM and IgG antibodies against N 35 protein of SARS-CoV-2 was used to screen the serums of 238 admitted hospital 36 patients between February 6 and February 14, 2020 with confirmed or suspected 37 SARS-CoV-2. SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detected on pharyngeal swab specimens using 38 real time RT-PCR. 194 (81.5%) of the serums were detected to be antibody (IgM 39 and/or IgG) positive, significantly higher than the positive rate of viral RNA (64.3%). 40 There was no difference in the positive rate of antibodies between the confirmed 41 patients (83.0%, 127/153) and the suspected patients (78.8%, 67/85), whose nucleic 42 acid tests were negative. The antibody positive rates were very low in the first five 43 days after initial onset of symptoms, and then rapidly increased as the disease 44 progressed. After 10 days, the antibody positive rates jumped from below 50% to over 45 80%. However, the positive rates of viral RNA maintained above 60% in the first 11 46 days after initial onset of symptoms, and then rapidly decreased. Overall, the 47 1. Due to having a low number of 224 samples for each individual day, we pooled the samples in which the positive rates 225 were similar in consecutive days. Thus, the disease process was divided into five 226 phases of 0-5 days, 6-10 days,11-12 days, 13-15 days and more than 16 days after 227 initial onset of symptoms (Table 3 & Fig.2) . The data show that the positive rates of 228 IgM and/or IgG are extremely low in the first five days after initial onset of symptoms 229 because no antibodies are produced in the majority of patients at this early stage, and rapidly increase as the disease progresses. Day 11 after initial onset of symptoms is a 231 key point because the positive rates of IgM and/or IgG jump to over 80% from less 232 than 50%. The sensitivity of antibody detection reaches to more than 93% since day 233 11 after initial onset of symptoms. This dynamic trend is consistent with SARS-CoV 234 infection [22] . In comparison, the real-time RT-PCR was more effective for detecting 235 SARS-CoV-2 infection than ELISA in the early stage of the disease. The positive rate 236 of viral RNA detected by RT-PCR was maintained above 60% in the first 11 days after 237 initial onset of symptoms, and rapidly decreased with the rapid increase of antibodies. 238 These results demonstrate that ELISA-based IgM and/or IgG detection should be used 239 as a major viral diagnostic test for patients with symptoms for more than 10 days. 240 Given that 50% of clinically suspected patients with symptoms for 6-10 days were 241 detected to be positive by ELISA-based IgM and/or IgG detection (Table 4)

FIGREF2.text: with 200 μL of virus preservation solution. Total RNA was extracted 123 using the respiratory sample RNA isolation kit (Shuoshi, Shanghai, China). After 124 vortex, 50 μL of cell lysates were transferred into another collection tube. The 125 collection tube was centrifugated at 1000 rpm/min for 5 min after standing at room 126 temperature for 10 minutes. 5 μL RNA was prepared and used for real time RT-PCR. 127 Real time RT-PCR was performed using the nucleic acid testing kit (Daan, 128 Guangzhou, China) for SARS-CoV-2 detection. The open reading frame 1ab 129 (ORF1ab) and nucleocapsid protein (N) were simultaneously selected as the two 130 target genes. The human GAPDH gene was used as an internal control. The specific 131 primers and probes set for ORF1ab and N were as follows: ORF1ab--VIC-TCCTGCTAGAATGGCTGGCAATGGCG-BHQ1-3'. The real time RT-PCR 138 experiment was thoroughly performed according to the kit's instructions. The reaction 139 mixture contains 17 μL of reaction buffer A, 3 μL of reaction buffer B, and 5 μL RNA 140 template. The real time RT-PCR assay was performed under the following conditions: 141 incubation at 50 °C for 15 min and 95 °C for 15 min, 45 cycles of denaturation at 94 °C for 15 s, and extension and collection of fluorescence signal at 55 °C for 45 s. Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) 146 Serological assay was performed using an Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assays 147 kit (Lizhu, Zhuhai, China ), which was developed for detecting IgM or IgG antibody 148 against N proteins of SARS-CoV-2. For IgM detection, ELISA plates were previously 149 coated with mouse anti-human IgM (μ chain) monoclonal antibody. 100 μL of diluted 150 (1:100) serum sample was added to the pre-coated plates with three replicating wells 151 for each sample and incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. The heat-inactivated positive and 152 negative serums were included on each plate. After washing, 100 μL of horse radish 153 peroxidase (HRP) conjugated recombinant (rN) protein of SARS-CoV-2 were added. 154 The plate was incubated at 37 °C for 30 min and then washed. 50 μL of TMB 155 substrate solution and 50 μL of the corresponding buffer were added and incubated at 156 37 °C for 15 min. The reaction was terminated by adding 50 μL of 2 M sulfuric acid, 157 and the absorbance value at 450 nm (A 450 ) was determined. The cut off value was 158 calculated using the sum of 0.100 and average A 450 of the negative control replicates. 159 A 450 less than cut off value was defined as a negative test, and A 450 greater than or 160 equal to cut off value was defined as a positive test. 161 For IgG detection, ELISA plates were previously coated with rN protein. 5 μL of 162 serum sample diluted with 100 μL of dilution buffer were added to the plates. After 163 incubation and washing, HRP-conjugated mouse anti-human IgG monoclonal antibody was added to the plates for detection. The other operational steps were 165 performed as described in the above IgM detection. The cut off value was calculated 166 using the sum of 0.130 and average A 450 of the negative control replicates. A 450 less 167 than cut off value was defined as a negative test, and A 450 greater than or equal to cut 168 off value was defined as a positive test. 169 2.4. Statistical analysis 170 Continuous variables were described in the form of means and standard deviations 171 or medians and interquartile ranges (IQR). Categorical variables were expressed as 172 counts and percentages. Independent group t tests were applied to continuous 173 variables that were normally distributed; otherwise, the Mann-Whitney test was used. 174 Categorical variables were compared using the chi-square tests, while the Fisher exact 175 test was used when data was limited. Statistical analyses were performed using 176 Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 22.0 software.

Although serological assay is a frequently used method for viral 249 infection screening and diagnosis, there are few reports on serological assay in the 250 detection of SARS-CoV-2. In this study, we evaluate the application of the 251 SARS-CoV-2 N protein-based ELISA for detection of IgM and IgG antibodies in admitted hospital patients with confirmed or suspected SARS-CoV-2 infections. The 253 results show that the positive rate of antibodies detected by ELISA was significantly 254 higher than that of viral RNA detected by real-time RT-PCR across all the enrolled 255 patients, suggesting that antibody detection is more sensitive than viral nucleic acid 256 test to diagnose SARS-CoV2 infection. More importantly, the suspected patients 257 exhibited nearly the same antibody detection rate as the confirmed patients. This data 258 strongly demonstrates that the majority of suspected patients, who were tested 259 negative for viral RNA, were in fact infected by SARS-CoV-2. 260 In this study, serum samples were collected in a time period of 9 days from 261 patients in different stages of the disease. The positive rates of nucleic acid test and 262 serological assay in total populations cannot reflect their diagnostic value in 263 surveillance and control of the disease. In order to objectively determine the disease 264 stage of the patients, we used the initial onset of symptoms exhibited by the patients 265 as the starting time point. All patients were defined to different stages of disease based 266 on when the test sample was collected. The dynamics patterns of positive rates of viral 267 RNA and antiviral antibodies confirmed the rationality of the definition of disease 268 stage. Our analysis identified the 11th day after initial onset of symptoms as a key 269 time point in the disease process. This is when most infected patients produce 270 antiviral antibodies. After the 11 th day, the diagnosis of viral infection should mainly 271 depend on serological assays. Before the 11 th day, the nucleic acid test is important for 272 confirmation of viral infection. The combination of serological assay and viral nucleic 273 acid test can greatly improve the diagnostic efficacy. TABREF0.text: ). The S protein homotrimers are required for attachment to host 69 receptors [9], and both the M protein and the E protein play important roles in 70 virus assembly [10,11]. The N protein is responsible for packaging the encapsidated 71 genome into virions [12,13], and acts as a viral RNA silencing suppressor that is 72 beneficial for the viral replication [14]. Furthermore, the N protein has high73 immunogenic activity and is profusely overexpressed during infection [15]. Thus, the 74 N protein is a potential source of diagnostic antigen for detecting the SARS-CoV-2 75 infection. Many diagnostic methods based on the N protein have been developed for detecting SARS-CoV [16-18]. In addition, different CoVs possess special structural 77 and accessory proteins, such as the HE protein, 3a/b protein, and 4a/b protein [19]. Both nucleic acid tests and serological assays are commonly used for infectious 79 disease screening and diagnosis. In the present case of SARS-CoV-2 in China, nucleic 80 acid tests are routinely used to detect causative viruses from respiratory secretions 81 using real-time RT-PCR. However, the nucleic acid tests appear to have a high false 82 negative rate due to various unavoidable factors, including the sensitivity of the 83 detection kits, and the sampling location and technique [20]. A large number of 84 clinically-suspected patients, whose nucleic acid tests are negative, are unable to get 85 timely hospitalization, potentially promoting the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and disease 86 progression of suspected patients. In this study, a newly-developed IgM and IgG antibod detecting Enzyme-linked 88 immunosorbent assays (ELISA) based on a recombinant fragment of the SARS-CoV-2 N protein was used to detect IgM and IgG against SARS-CoV-2 in the 90 serums of 238 admitted hospital patients with confirmed or suspected SARS-CoV-2 91 infections. The results strongly indicate that the suspected patients were in fact 92 infected. We also analyzed the diagnostic value of the IgM and IgG testing in COVID-19, even in the early stages of the disease.
